lines.text: [before fighting Asa Watts]
I'm thirty years older than you are. I had my back broke once, and my hip twice. And on my worst day I could beat the hell out of you.

[smiles, shakes his head]
I don't think so.
You will.
[Knocks him down with a big left]

[referring to the madam Kate Collingwood's offer of sexual favor]
Well, I have the inclination, the maturity, and the wherewithal... but unfortunately, I don't have the time.
You all right, boy?
Yes, sir. My name's Clyde Potter. They call me Fats.
Tend toward the gut myself.
Slap some bacon on a biscuit and let's go! We're burnin' daylight!

[praying to God before he's about to hanged by Asa Watts and his gang]
I regret trifling with married women. I'm thoroughly ashamed at cheating at cards. I deplore my occasional departures from the truth. Forgive me for taking your name in vain, my Saturday drunkenness, my Sunday sloth. Above all, forgive me for the men I've killed in anger
[eyes shifting to Asa Watts]
... and those I am about to.
They didn't even dig him a decent grave.
Well, it's not how you're buried, it's how you're remembered.
I'm proud of ya... All of ya. Every man wants his children to be better'n he was. You are.
What's sugar tits?
[repeated line]
We're burnin' daylight.

This may seem a lonesome place to leave him, but he is not alone, because many of his kind rest here with him. The prairie was like a mother to Mr. Andersen. He belonged to her. She cared for him while he lived. And she is nursing him while he sleeps.
I never noticed before, but most of the people I know are quiet compared to Mr. Andersen.
He's quiet... it just comes out loud.
Son-of-a-bitch.
What did you say?
You god-damned son-of-a-bitch!
Say that again.
You god-damned, mean, son-of-a-bitch!
Say it faster.
You god-damned, mean, dirty, son-of-a-bitch!
I wouldn't make it a habit of calling me that, son.
You're a hard man, Mr. Andersen.
It's a hard life.
You look like the vermin-ridden son of a bitch you are.
Big mouth don't make a big man.

Sometimes it's hard to understand the drift of things. This was a good boy. He'd have been a good man. He didn't get his chance. Death can come for ya any place, any time. It's never welcomed. But if you've done all you can do, and it's your best, in a way I guess you're ready for it.
I'm a man and yer boys. Not cowmen, not by a damn sight, nothing but cowboys just like the word says. And I'm gonna remind you of it every single minute of every day and night.
Now I don't hold jail against you, but I hate a liar.
A fool comes to town with a fistful of gold dust, and every jackass from 50 miles around lights out after him.
There ain't a kid in that school over fifteen. They're between hay and grass. I need men.
How old was you when you went on your first cattle drive?
What difference does that make?
How old was you, Wil?
Well, in my day...
How old?
Thirteen! But my old man's pants fit me!
If you're lying, remember one thing. I could swallow each of you whole without choking. All I need do is butter your heads and pin your ears back.
My name's Homer Weems, Mr. Andersen. And I hope I ain't rode all the rough off of him.

[to Wil]
My name's Honeycutt. I'm fifteen, and everybody calls me Slim.

Now... this is the "Double O", this is Belle Fourche. In between is four hundred miles of the meanest country in the West. And the only way we're gonna get through is if you take orders. Is that clear?
Yes, sir.
00 a.m. And come with grit teeth, 'cuz gentlemen, that's when school really begins.
Mr. Nightlinger, are you black all over?
'Cept for the whites of my eyes.
Is... your...?
It is... black, too.
See? He's the same as us, 'cept for that color.
The same as you?
[turns around slowly with a huge knife in hand and chuckles]
The same as you?
[guffaws loudly as the boys huddle together, startled]
Ohhh, children... My father was a brawny Moor, six feet six inches tall. He bound his head in a red velvet cloth
[hands knife to Slim and the boys relax, but listen]

he wore a curved sword, forged from the finest Toledo steel. He captured a lady, bright and dark. he took her in his arms and wrapped her in a warm quilt and carried her off. They came to a castle and he battered down the doors with the trunk of an oak tree and KILLED EVERYBODY IN IT, just so they could rest the night. Later, while she slept, he walked the parapets... and became a king.

[in awe]
Is that true?
If it isn't, it oughta be...
Where's your head man?
That's Mr. Andersen, he's over at Ft. Smith.
Alright, then. What's your name?
They call me Cimarron.
I'm Kate, to my friends. Ha-ha. And who's the one with the pretty pink blush?
This here's Homer.
Hello, Homer.
Ma'am.
How many men you got in your outfit, Cimarron?
Well, if you're going by age, we got, eh, two that's 15.
My, god.
[Kate's troop of ladies giggle]
If you're going by what we can do, there's 11 of us!
No offense. In this kind of country, a poor helpless woman likes to know if there are any men around. I mean, men who can take care of us, as we, go along our way.
Well, we're gettin' paid a man's wages.
And you look man enough to earn them, too, Cimarron.
My name is Nightlinger, and I'm in charge of these boys.
My name is Mrs. Collingwood, and I'm, uh... in charge of these girls.
I just heard from a highly exited youngster that there were some soiled doves winging through here.

[laughing]
Well... what do you want from me?
Madam, you know young boys... they dream of golden skin and unbound hair. Even if I could lock them up they would find a way of getting here.
There is very little I could do about that.

I'm sure you would handle everything most tastefully. It's a question of, uh... waiting for a more appropriate time in their lives. Perhaps it would be wiser to wait until next year... or even the year after.
With any luck, I'll be retired by then. Well... the first time should be in the back of a buggy with a... girl that they think they're in love with. Alright... we'll move on.
You are a charming and sensible lady.
What about you?
Well, I have the inclination... the maturity... and the wherewithal... but unfortunately, I don't have the time.
[Both laugh]
Wil, if yer neck was any stiffer, you couldn't even bend down ta pull yer boots on!

You know, trail driving is not Sunday school picnic. You got to figure you're dealing with the dumbest oneriest critter on God's green earth. The cow is nothing but trouble tied up in a leather bag - and the horse ain't much better.
The first time should be in the back of a buggy with a girl that they think they're in love with.
[the boys are acting innocent, while scheming to steal a bottle of whiskey]
Boys are always guilty of something nasty. What could it be this time, I wonder?
Doesn't anything larger want to work for you?
It smells of boy in here.
You're staring at me, children. I feel your eyes on my back. Now why is that?
I like to travel with a man I'm used to.
You'll get used to me.
Miserable.
Who's first?
I'll go first.
You know in the late war between the states I served under an officer just like you.
Is that right?
As a matter of fact I shot that military gentlemen in the buttocks. Just outside Vicksburg.
I'd of hung ya.
They gave me a medal.
In my regiment, Mr. Nightlinger, I was known as 'Old Ironpants'. You might keep that in mind!
Did you ever think of hiring boys?
What boys?
School boys.
Oh sure and women. How about my ma in Cedar City. She's only ninety two.
Well you ain't got a lot of choice.

What are you gonna use for hands on this drive of yours, huh? Them little bitty boys down there? Come on, you know better than that, Mr. Andersen. You know what you're gonna need to trundle them boys across the prairie, don't you? A baby carriage.
Well whatever I need I'll get.

Don't you point to your ears now, son, because you ain't running back to Mr. Wil Andersen with those eyes rolling in the back of your head telling him there's these real bad men have been following us day and night. You're not gonna say that because I'm gonna come to you some night when it's real dark. I'm gonna come to you on tip toe so you ain't ever gonna be able to hear me.
An' if you run into any trouble, call Anse Peterson.
Will, Anse Peterson is sixty years old.

[smiling]
Annie, so am I.
My oldest son would have been forty this year. Middle aged. But they went bad on me... or I went bad on them.

[pointing at Fats]
You - what started this?
He talked about Slim's mother. He said "Tu madre es puta." You understand Spanish Mr. Andersen?
Yeah.
So does Slim.
Your word? Well, here's my word. Get the hell off my spread, now!
I'll think about ya 'fore I go to bed at night.
You do and you won't sleep.
Did you want me for anything, Mrs. Collingwood?
That's Phoebe. You're, eh, putting too much merchandise on display, Phoebe. You better cover some of that up before you come down with pneumonia.
Isn't this a sweet lookin' boy.
[Walks towards Homer on his horse]
Wouldn't you like to come inside, honey? You'd be surprised how nice we got everything fixed up.
[Homer, scared, rides off on his horse]
Well, I think that Homer just saved himself a dollar.
